item.title: Hearing for Injunction to Stop Sweeps Starts Monday!! Jan 11th ...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

Hearing for Injunction to Stop Sweeps Starts Monday!! Jan 11th

Public audio access to the hearing, please call 877-336-1828 and enter access code 9449909#.you can call to listen to the hearing January 11, 2021 starting at 9am.

The more that are lstening the more accountable we can keep them.

...

On December 15th and 16th, 2020, Federal District 10 Judge Martinez heard our case against the City of Denver and the State of Colorado for violating constitutional rights by sweeping people without homes and with nowhere to go - even in a global pandemic. We have our third day of testimony on Monday January 11. 2021 at 9am.This suit demands that sweeps be halted, at least during the COVID pandemic, to protect the health and safety of the community with and without housing - as in line with CDC guidance. The suit states, “The CDC issued this guidance because conducting sweeps significantly increases the risk to homeless individuals, and the community, of infection with COVID-19. Despite this clear warning, the defendants chose to act in direct contradiction of public health guidance and to violate the property and due process rights of homeless individuals in a cruel and dangerous manner.”

On top of this the suit addresses that, “Over the past year, and in a blatant effort to skirt a settlement agreement entered into between Denver and a class of its homeless population, Denver officials have repeatedly showed up at homeless encampments without notice, flatly told homeless residents to move along (“to where?” is the obvious question to this nonsensical command), and seized their property (often discarding it).” The City cannot get away with these violations of the lawsuit settlement agreement nor with the blatant disregard for the health of those who can’t afford housing during this pandemic.

Plaintiffs for this case lost all their property in sweeps, including a mass sweep of Lincoln Park conducted by the City and State together on July 29th, 2020 with no notice. One plaintiff, Charles explains how after gathering all he could in one trip to move from the park that morning, that “when I returned to the spot where my tent had been, I found that it had been taken and destroyed by Denver officials, along with everything in it.” Hundreds of people lost all their property in that one sweep. These same hundreds of people have been chased around the City in sweep after sweep since that time.

Due to COVID regulations people will not be able to attend the hearing in person. You can call 877-336-1828 and enter access code 9449909# to listen to the hearing.

item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

Read the full comments... also know the Mayor McAddams of SLC tried this PR stunt a few years ago. Remember it was not that many years ago the Aurora would not publicly acknowledge that they had homelessness. “We don't have homelessness” was the refrain. Most likely hoping to drive them all into the inner city ... a common suburban tactic.

Colorado Village Collaborative

This afternoon we issued a five point rebuttal of Aurora Mayor Mike Coffman's conclusions following his recent urban camping experience. In response to the Auro...ra Mayor's egregious comments about homelessness as "a lifestyle choice" and a product of "drug culture," we assert the following:

1) Homeless people did not cause mass homelessness.
2) Homelessness is a housing problem.
3) Homelessness disproportionately impacts BIPOC communities.
4) Trauma and adverse childhood experiences are the leading causes of substance misuse.
5) Housing and services end homelessness.

item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

SWEEPS UPDATE:
Yesterday morning, once again, our city's DDPHE, DOTI, EHS, DFD, and DPD were out traumatically displacing our unhoused community members. Fencing went up Tuesday afternoon around 4:30pm. Approximately 20 Denver residents were traumatically displaced by the very people charged with serving and protecting them.

This morning at 11th and Acoma fencing went up at 5am. Approximately 40 people were traumatically displaced by our city. There was a greater police presence to traumatically displace residents they swore to serve and protect than were present yesterday at the Capitol when hundreds of Trump supporters protested in riot gear for hours. We can clearly see whose interests our city seeks to protect.

item.title: "The decision to not prioritize people living in shelters...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

"The decision to not prioritize people living in shelters appears even more counterintuitive after a year of seemingly constant homeless encampment sweeps, continuously displacing people in the midst of a pandemic. If we want people to stay in shelters rather than tents, shouldn’t we try to make it safer for folks to do so?
. . .
I’ve spoken to several people experiencing homelessness who have shared that their biggest concern about staying in a shelter is COVID, and feel tha...t staying outside (especially in the warmer months) is safer than sleeping in a congregate setting. That concern has proven to be legitimate. Because of the prevalence of asymptomatic carriers, screening for and tracking symptoms haven’t been enough to prevent outbreaks within shelters. Positivity rates in homeless shelters here in Denver have been higher than in the general population, and smaller shelters in Colorado have had an even harder time limiting the spread."

item.title: Happy New Year? Despite claims to the contrary, this is...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

Happy New Year?

Despite claims to the contrary, this is designed to move people out of the area. The department of transportation is but one option of many that the city uses to move people out of sight. There is no declaration of where people can go, and in what manner. The only thing that is described is where property can go because that is all the city is concerned with... property and not people. Our laws will reflect it.

We will see if the city just address the encumbrances, cleans and then moves on or if they evict people just hanging on. Without a declared option of where they can go this is problematic. A problem we have been concerned with for a long time.

item.title: The courts offered a call in number to listen to the proceedings...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

The courts offered a call in number to listen to the proceedings on the first two days and will likely do so again for the final day of testimony. We will keep you updated on the on that information becomes available. The cities testimony was hurt themselves greatly on day 2... the courts require you to tell the truth, it will be interesting to see how they finish up, and how the Judge rules the case.

What is more important is that these stupid sweeps end for good and we use all that energy to work on making things better for our homeless instead of harder. Things like acces to bathrooms, trash removal etc.
